description: What a long day of travel!  Must sleep

photos.caption: This is what my brain looks like after 24 hours of continuous travel

description: Just really wanted a slow kickback day and not much honestly planned for BK.  So just tooled around the local streets.

photos.caption: A much needed slow day.  So yeah, you get a black building.
More like Vomitism amiright?

description: The focus of this day was FOOD TOUR!  5 people on the tour + 2 guides.  15 dishes.  Walked around Chinatown sampling a nice array of Thai specialties (primarily street food).  All of it was excellent.  Some of it surprising and a few really incredible dishes.

photos.caption: Mall tour - a massive mall
Bangkok sidewalks are loads of fun
Food tour - kitty not on the menu
Saw all these vines above this alley  - waitaminute, those aren't vines
Food tour:  Thai pork leg stew
Making chive dumplings along the food tour
The bbq'd chive dumplings - very unique and very good
Thai sukiyaki - very good
On the food tour in Chinatown
Was taking this picture of this door and as I shot it this little boy came out from behind it
My favorite dish of the food tour:  green curry. Very subtle, incredible flavors wth just the right spice
Hot (white) pepper stew with crunchy pork - amazing
I was pressured to try the Thai durian and to be fair it was the best durian I've ever had
Food tour - making Thai donuts
Alley in Chinatown lit at night
Street food in Chinatown Mon-Sat - huge crowds and this is the offseason

description: Escaped the creepy weirdness of Bangkok for a calmer place here in Chiang Mai, in northern Thailand.  Got in pretty early but the heat wasn't motivating for touring around.  I went out at 7pm and it had cooled off by at least 10 degrees and few people were around.  This might be the plan (+ early mornings).  Then take refuge during the heat of day.  Had my first Khao Soi from its birth-region and it didn't disappoint.  I might write more about this dish later.  Not sure how long I'll be in CM - winging it at this point.

photos.caption: Khao Soi with chicken - wow
Silly dog at Wat Phra Singh
Wat Phra Singh
Wat Phra Singh with monk walking by - many of them doing monk things whatever monk things are
Wat Phra Singh - night time is best time
Wat Phra Singh - 10 deg cooler and very few people around
Wat Phra Singh
Small street in Chiang Mai
Mango Sticky Rice - a favorite

description: Early morning I was off to tour the local temples (there are many of them).  So few people were at the temples at that hour so that was a big win.  Weather is tolerable in the morning.  By about 9am it starts getting pretty brutal out of the shade.  I will have no updates tomorrow as I'll be on a jungle hike/tour, staying the night at a tribal village.

photos.caption: Tree at Wat Chedi Luang.  It's so weird - there aren't a lot of trees in Chiang Mai, then you see this massive unit of a tree
Wat Chedi Luang - one of many temples at this site
Wat Chedi Luang - interior of a more modern temple
Wat Chedi Luang
Wat Chedi Luang - a 15th century temple - incredible
Elephants on the Wat Chedi Luang temple
I sorely wanted to Bang This Gong
Eddie Van Thailand wails during the solo
Saw a good boy as I peeked thru a gate in Chiang Mai
Back to Wat Phra Singh but inside this time.  They like their big Buddha's here but this is an especially big one.

description: What a spectacular and challenging day.  I took a guided overnight tour that consisted of 3 parts.  A hike to a Karen Hill Tribe village in the mountains outside of Chiang Mai, an overnight stay and a return hike, then a visit to an elephant refuge and finally a float down this beautiful river on a bamboo raft.  That last one was super fun but no pics as I was worried about the phone.  This day was very challenging due to the combination of very significant heat and very steep climbs.  But we were rewarded with beautiful jungle scenery and rice paddies, an amazing waterfall, and finally the tribal village of the Karen people.  THey were very friendly and while very, very rustic the stay was a nice one.

photos.caption: Beautiful rice paddies
Making our way towards the tribal village.  It was insanely hot in the sun and the amount of fluids that poured out of my skin was unbelievable
This saved the day as we cooled off here.  It was an amazing waterfall with a large cave behind it.  We had lunch at this beautiful spot
Sad, little pupper at the lunch stop
Behind the waterfall - generally I turn my nose up at waterfalls these days but this one was exceptional and there were few people around
A rare sighting of me - at the waterfall

Our tour guide Moon as we had lunch.  BTW, those little bananas were insanely good.  Like bananas on steroids.  They were as sweet as a Honeycrisp apple and packed with intense banana flavor.  Incredible.
This local guy was staggering around and finally fully passed out - he was totally stoned
Two nice puppers at the waterfall stop
Continuing our trek to the tribal village.  The heat I tell you, THE HEAT...
Water buffalo being tended by their caretaker.  These animals were suprisingly cute.  I'm mean like way cuter than a cow.
Heading towards the active rice fields of the Karen tribal village
The route was flooded so off with the shoes
Local farmers preparing the rice paddies
Our guide acting as chef for the evening cooking over an open fire
Dinner at our "hotel"

description: We were awakened at 5am by the roosters, dogs, chickens, pigs, and all sorts of activities.  Had a simple breakfast then it was 2 hours of hiking to another waterfall and our final destination.  It was another very hot day with extrememly steep climbs and descents.  The mosquitos were there but not too hectic.  Incredible scenery all around us.  We visited an elephant 'sanctuary' which really is just a money generating business where the elephants are paraded in front of you in close proximity.  Not my favorite sort of enterprise but it was a treat to see an Asian elephant up so close.  Then we went on a river float on bamboo rafts.  Very peaceful with some gentle rapids and a very nice finish to another arduous day.  Look for photo icons to the SW of Chiang Mai if you're interested in seeing where this trek was.

photos.caption: Hiking crew at the start of the 2nd day
Rice paddies along the beautiful trail
It was breathtaking out there
More rice paddies along the way
These were flooded so we had to balance carefully
Behind this view is a beautiful waterfall but who wants to see more waterfall pics?
Our tour guide disappeared for about 20 min as we swam in the pool of the waterfall
Such a beautiful countryside.  After this it was an insanely steep climb and the cooling effect of the swim rapidly vanished
There was an elephant "sanctuary" tagged to the end of the trip.  I mean it is was it is but it was still nice to see an elephant up so close
WTF - at the Chiang Mai Sunday Night Market - a MASSIVE street market, miles long

description: Not too many photos since this was a travel day.  About 4 hours in an utterly packed van filled with young folk and luggage.  It's a fairly dangerous 2-lane road to Pai, filled with huge trucks and blind turns and it rained during the 2nd half so it was a little but of a knuckle-biter.  Pai, as I'm discovering is very, very much a young person town.  And when people say it's a hippie place they really just mean it's a place for getting high.  O guess I should have realized but I just assumed that was like a part of it while I think it's really the main part of it.  So...  I still need to see what kinds of activities more my speed are available - that's my job tomorrow.  I may only be here 3 nights or so - we'll see.

photos.caption: More Khao Soi - more good taste
On the drive from Chiang Mai to Pai
Pai at night
Across the street from my hotel:  3 weed stores side-by-side
My bungalow - it's quite nice

description: It was a slow day today as I really just wanted to relax.  So it's another slow photo day.  Did a little research for tomorrow and for the next transport.  Planning some tours tomorrow.

photos.caption: Place I'm staying at is probably the nicest one so far
Koi pond at my hotel
Another street shot in Pai

description: Did the standard 1/2-day tour in these parts.  A few lame stops but it ended with a few great ones.  There are some really beautiful areas around here and the intermittent rains added to the mood of the place.

photos.caption: Guard dog to the giant buddha.  He's got a little bumhole.
One of the overlooks near Pai
Heading to the requisite waterfall stop

2 minutes after I paid to get in and got to the waterfall, the head honcho came up, waving crazily at these 2 guys on the opposite bank.  It had been raining hard and the water was very rapidly rising.  We all had to get out of there which was a little spooky.
Puppers at the coffee shop stop
Another puppers at the coffee shop stop.  Puppers and coffee - what else can you ask for?
The dogs here are fearless and commonly lay in the road
This place was known as "Bamboo Bridge".  It was a series of well, bamboo bridges, with fantastic views all around
A hut sort of thing at the bamboo bridges
Rice paddies at Bamboo Bridge
More rice paddies at Bamboo Bridge
Rice paddies, etc. at the bamboo bridges
Temple at the bamboo bridges
Pai Canyon, where we were to watch the sunset.  There was to be no sunset, in large part because our tour made us leave before the sunset and also due to the rainy skies
Pai Canyon

description: Another travel day via minivan.  Had to backtrack to Chiang Mai then it was on to Chiang Rai.  Oddly enough, the prior city I was in was Pai and not Chiang Pai.  Why?  Maybe Chiang just wasn't in the picture for the founding.  Or maybe... we just shouldn't ask such questions.

photos.caption: The heavy rains yesterday took their toll on the ride out of Pai.  Mountainsides lost their grip and tumbled onto the 2-lane mountain road
Boulder + mud = boulder on road
A very new buddhist temple in Chiang Rai - super awesome looking
Temple detail
Temple
More temple detail
Detail of a gold temple on the same property
Super cool statue representing who knows what.  Notice the claw coming out at the edge of the water channel.
The apparently famous clock tour in Chiang Rai.  This thing has an evening light show every hour.  I hate to spoil the city pride about this thing but it's a pretty lame-ass light show.
I give you the band "Ebola" - that's a pretty baller name.
It wasn't crazy hot but with the very high humidity it doesn't take much to get dehydrated.  This is me re-hydrating right before the heavens opened up.

description: Mostly a chill and organizing day.  Got my passport photos for my upcoming Laos border crossing.  Booked the standard Chiang Rai all-day tour for tomorrow.  And booked my pickup / border crossing / slow-boat ride to my first destination in Laos on Sunday.  It's a 2 day boat ride (I mean, they call it the slow boat) down the Mekong River with an overnight stay along the way.

photos.caption: The Pink Milk Cheese sounds amazing!
Roti Bom - something I've dreamed about for years since having in Malaysia many, many years ago.  Finally!  It's a dessert thing with sweetened condensed milk added and in this case fresh banana.
Roti Bom with banana (they don't use the "Bom" here - but that's how I've always known it from Malaysia)

description: It was a very long tour day with some really great stops.  Re-visited the White Temple which still just blows me away.  The artist who made this is just a genius.  There was a gallery of his stuff that was also incredible.  And the big bonus was a section I missed the first time called The Art Cave (or Art Garden - I think Cave...).  Just phenomenal.  This cave had so much detail with cool lighting, sculptures, music.  I found it hard to leave.  Then we hit the Blue Temple - another very cool, very modern temple not too dissimilar from the White Temple style.  Then the Black House or something like that which was an artist's (since passed) installation on this large property.  A lot of dark themes and unusual furniture and sculptures.  Another great installation.  Then to the tea farm which was pretty neato - Oolong tea tasting on a beautiful property.  Then the Tall Neck Village - which honestly was a little uncomfortable - but these people rely on this income as they are refugees from Myanmar.  You've surely seen at some point a documentary where the women of this tribe wear brass rings stacked on their necks that elongates them.  The older women still had these as did a few of the younger ones.  Felt weird taking pics so I didn't.  It was nice as there wasn't really a crowd and children were around playing their normal children games so the vibe was mostly fine.  Then the Golden Triangle which is the intersection of Thailand, Myanmar, and Laos.  Oh, and the Opium Museum which was sorta interesting - especially in that the area we spent most of the day in used to be predominantly occupied by opium fields.  Finally a quick stop at the Saturday Night Market in Chiang Rai, which I can still hear as I type this right before bed.  I have a very early morning tomorrow as I start my journey to Laos.  Should be an interesting one and it just might not be all that enjoyable.  Let's see how it goes!

photos.caption: We are back at the White Temple today!  But no more white temple photos.  There were some amazing other things there I missed the 1st time!
The Art Garden (exterior).  I was blown away by this entire installation
TMNT in the Art Garden (exterior)
Aliens! Art Garden (exterior)
This is the Art Cave which is one of the cooler things I've seen in awhile
More Art Cave
More AC
MOAR AC
No, really, we need some AC in here it's pretty dang hot
AC
Not sure if supposed to be Chucky?
Shark!
Rad AC hallway.  And there was cool music throughout - check the vids!
AC
I seriously thought this was anothe Art Cave thing when outside but then it just every so slightly moved its head
The Blue Temple - also very modern and very cool
Blue Temple sculpture
Blue Temple
Rad Blue Temple sculpture
BT!
BbbbbTttttt
bt
I forgot the name of this place - something like Black House.  It's an art installation across a property from a single artist.  Very dark and very cool
Dark house with very awesome natural rock sculptures
Inside one of the strange buildings on the site
This is a very cute cat pic.
Dark house
MOAR Dark House
So many awesome carvings on the doors to this building
Carving detail
Dark house
Dark house with more detail of the awesome rocks I was in love with

Ok - this was a weird stop.  "Tall neck tribe village".  These are the tribal people known for the women with neck rings that elongate their necks.  I didn't take pics of them because I felt weird about it.  They are refugees from Myanmar and make their living from visits like ours.
Obligatory pupper from Long Neck Village.  This one's name was Sticky Rice.
We went to a team farm and did a tasting - this was Oolong tea,.
Tea farm
Final stop, the Golden Triangle.  That triangular jutting of the land is the intersection of Thailand, Myanmar, and Laos.  A cool stop.
We also visited this museum - no tastings at this one wtf?
Yet another night market - this one in Chiang Rai - super popular and packed.

description: A big travel day.  Went through Laos immigration and I have one weird story.  They want US$40 for the Visa.  I was warned they are very particular about the state of the bills themselves.  It turns out they are VERY, VERY particular.  Like no spots, crease marks, or defects of literally ANY kind.  I had 5 20's turned down and they finally took my 2nd $100 bill.  What a dump thing - they have some sort of money fetish here.  Also, $1 USD is equal to 21,340 Laotian "Kip".  Yeah.  I was told they take Thai Baht so I loaded up on that but I think that was a mistake because now I'm having to do 2 conversions just to know how much something is.  And they give you Kip for change anyhow so there's no avoiding it.  Sort of a mess but I'm sure I'll get around it.  Had a minor bad experience at the town we stopped - it's fully a we-got-you tourist trap and I some old guy hijacked my bag and insisted on payment for carrying it to shore afterwards.  Sux.  I suspect it's just this crappy town.  Hotel pretty rustic but at $13 per night what do you want?  So it's another long boat day tomorrow then hopefully things will be much better in Luang Prabang and I forked over for a pretty nice hotel there (like $35/night!!).

photos.caption: All aboard the slow boat!
Cool bug on slow boat
My view from my seat
Down the Mekong River
Some nice views along the river
The boat ride itself was ~6 hours.  But that's just the 1st day haha
Our boat captains
Views of Laos
More Laos as we get close to our 1st stop
This is Pakbeng - spending the night here then more slow boat tomorrow
Nice view of the Mekong from my pretty spartan hotel room

description: Another Slow Boat Day and after another 6+ hours, I'm quite over Slow Boat for now.  I expect to be relaxing tomorrow, maybe checking out some local food.  Maybe a tour the following day.  Here for at least 4 nights - maybe more.

photos.caption: A view of where I stayed the previous night as we roll on out for Slow Boat 2:  The Boatening
Very much the same scenery today which isn't a bad thing
We probably made 8 stops at local villages, picking up and dropping off locals.  This family was one of them.
Local little girl checking out the local scenery
This must have a name but I don't know it yet.  It's not far from my day's destination: Luang Prabang
Part of the prior pics formation.  There's a naturally hollowed out portion which appears to house a temple.  No doubt this will be on one of the standard tours so I expect to be back.
Close-up of the interior temple
In Luang Prabang on the Tuk Tuk to my hotel
This was from last night and was a phenomenal bowl of thin noodles in a coconut curry.  Just fantastic.  And the Lao IPA was pretty decent.

description: This was a much needed chill day.  Got my laundry in, got my tour for tomorrow sorted (full day), got my Vietnam E-Visa applied for, and had a little pool time.  Busy day tomorrow.

photos.caption: The Mekong River widens substantially by the time it reaches Luang Prabang
More temples, you say?  Well this is - a temple - in Luang Prabang
An older looking temple in Luang Prabang.  I know nothing of these.

This is the most aggressive front grill I've ever seen on a vehicle before.  It sort of looks like the camera moved as I was taking it.  There are tons of Chinese cars in SE Asia and I suspect this is one of them.  Quite a few electric vehicles as well, 95% Chinese.  But I did see a few Tesla's in Thailand.  No Cybertrucks tho.

Sometimes you just need to have some tacos and Luang Prabang delivered.  They were quite good with the Lao beer and I had a great conversation with the owner (Lao) and her friend (former American from SoCal).  It's these moments that really recharge the solo traveler.  Group tours are great for that as well.  On all of my group tours I've had fantatic tour-mates.

description: A very fun tour day around Luang Prabang. I didn't expect much from yet another waterfall but this one truly impressed and delivered - spectacular and crowds were reasonable.  We had a lame "tribal village" stop before this.  Next was - I think lunch, then a boat ride to the Buddha Cave, then a final Whiskey Village stop where we did local whiskey tastings - fun!  A very long, full day.  Great crowd and had some good conversations which is nice to keep the spirits up.

photos.caption: Sun Bear chillin'
Sun Dog chillin'.  And you can bet he got some pets, unlike the Sun Bear
Dennis chillin' at the Kuang Si waterfalls
I bitch about waterfalls a lot but due to the demand and the actually spectacular nature of this set of waterfalls, here you go:  many waterfall pics
One of six waterfall pools
A rad tree alongside the waterfall
So many cool sets of waterfalls here
Moar waterfall
MOAR WATERFALL
The king of the Kuang Si Falls - truly spectacular
Back on the Mekong
I swore I was done with slow boats, but today's tour put us on... wait for it... another slow boat
Mekong
Yeah - we're back at this site as I predicted
But first a detour to see this rad cliff
Rad cliff closeup
Group tour photo op.  The guy in the front right had Meta glasses on and he would save over and over in a light German accent:  "Meta, please take a picture"
View from - I dunno - I think it was the cave
Inside the Pak Ou caves (1 of 2)
This cave is known for the many Buddha statues placed
Many stairs down from Cave 1 of Pak Ou
Inside Cave 2 of Pak Ou
More Cave 2 Pak Ou
Cave 2 Pak Ou, catching a glimpse of the outside
Outside from inside at Pak Ou
Beautiful Mekong
Closing tour group photo

Our tour guide at the front of the boat - a great tour!  Oh - I didn't get pics of the Whiskey Village stop where we had many tastings of whiskey, followed up by beer on the boat ride home so we were in pretty high spirits (...get it?) by the time we arrived home

description: Today was a chill day.  I mainly just caught some breakfast, did a short hike up to the city-center temple, and did some planning and other things back at my hotel.  I have my transport for tomorrow to  Nong Khiaw as well as my accomodations which will be much more rustic compared to where I am now.  Nong Khiaw is supposed to be a scenic village up north and is about a 3.5 hour drive from here.  Currently planning 3 nights there.  Sadly I have to double-back to Luang Prabang when I leave but then there's just a relatively short 50 minute train to my following destination of Vang Vieng - which used to be a 5 hour car ride.

photos.caption: The long set of stairs to Wat Chom Si, near the city center
View from Wat Chom Si to the city center
Even monks like to sight-see
View towards the Mekong showing riverside Luang Prabang
View towards the East side of Luang Prabang
View of Wat Chom Si at the top
NE view of Luang Prabang from the top.  It's a nice, not-too-industrial city.

This is me less than an hour after having a normal shower, followed by a sweat shower from climbing those stairs.  Still air is the enemy here and it's suprising how much still air there is.  It seems like San Diego always has at least a small breeze.  Not so here.
